definitions.definition: an arrangement that somebody has with a bank, etc. to keep money there, take some out, etc.
definitions.labels: especially in British EnglishNorth American English usually(informal)(informal)(British English)(North American English)(informal)(informal)(informal)(British English)(US English)(formal)(especially North American English)(British English)(especially British English)(especially British English)(North American English usually)(informal)(informal)especially North American English

examples.text: I don't have a **bank account**.
I paid the money into my savings account.
a joint account *(= one in the name of more than one person)*
With internet banking you can manage your account online.
Do you have an account with us?
He **opened an account** at a bank in Germany.
Interest will be paid monthly into the **account holder**'s current account.
What's your account number please?
She deposited the check in her account.
I have a savings account with a building society.
I paid the cheque into my current account.
Your account is overdrawn.
They have a numbered account in Switzerland.
The money will be credited to your account tomorrow.
She opened a savings account at the bank.
She had taken all her money out of her account.
My husband and I have separate accounts.
I'd like to open an account, please.
I have an account with another bank.
Go and see the manager of the bank where your account is held.

definitions.definition: an arrangement that somebody has with a company that allows them to use the internet, send and receive messages by email, social media, etc.

examples.text: **an email/Instagram account**
Millions of accounts have been hacked.

definitions.definition: a written or spoken description of something that has happened

examples.text: an **eyewitness account** *(= a description given by somebody who saw what happened)*
a first-hand/personal/first-person account
Can you **give** us **an account** of what happened?
The diaries contain a **detailed account** of the writer's experiences on the voyage.
Dr Richards describes this very well in his account of the events.
She received a glowing account of her son's progress.
the newspaper account of the trial
She gave the police a full account of the incident.

definitions.definition: an explanation or a description of an idea, a theory or a process

examples.text: the Biblical account of the creation of the world

definitions.definition: a written record of money that is owed to a business and of money that has been paid by it

examples.text: to do the accounts
to keep the accounts up to date
the accounts department
She works in Accounts *(= the accounts department)*.
Try to keep accurate accounts.
The accounts are all in order.
Your accounts will need to be submitted to the tax office.

definitions.definition: an arrangement with a shop or business to pay bills for goods or services at a later time, for example in regular amounts every month
definitions.labels: British English alsoNorth American English also(North American English)

examples.text: Put it on my account please.
We have accounts with most of our suppliers.
Log in to your account to see how much you have spent.
Charge this to my account, please.
an account with a large store

definitions.definition: a bill for goods or services provided over a period

examples.text: Departing guests should **settle their accounts** at the office.
It is best to settle the account each month.

definitions.definition: a regular customer

examples.text: The agency has lost several of its most important accounts.

definitions.definition: a description of an event that gives you all the details in the order in which they happen

examples.text: He insisted on giving us a blow-by-blow account of what had happened.
She gave us a blow-by-blow account of the incident.

definitions.definition: according to what other people say

examples.text: I've never been there, but it's a lovely place, by all accounts.

definitions.definition: according to what you say yourself

examples.text: By his own account he had an unhappy childhood.

definitions.definition: to make somebody explain a mistake, etc. because they are responsible for it
to do something or perform well, especially in a contest

examples.text: The team gave a good account of themselves in the match.

definitions.definition: not important

examples.text: Emotional matters were of no account to them during the war.

definitions.definition: if you buy something or pay on account, you pay nothing or only a small amount immediately and the rest later

examples.text: Call a cab on account.
She bought the furniture she wanted on account.

definitions.definition: because of what you think somebody wants

examples.text: Please don't change your plans on my account.

definitions.definition: because of somebody/something

examples.text: She retired early on account of ill health.
The marsh is an area of great scientific interest on account of its wild flowers.

definitions.definition: not for any reason

examples.text: On no account should the house be left unlocked.

definitions.definition: for yourself

examples.text: In 2012 Smith set up in business on his own account.

definitions.definition: because you want to and you have decided, not somebody else

examples.text: No one sent me. I am here on my own account.

definitions.definition: because of the particular thing that has been mentioned

examples.text: Weather conditions were poor, but he did not delay his departure on that account.

definitions.definition: to use something in a good or helpful way

examples.text: He turned his artistic talents to good account by becoming a sculptor.

definitions.definition: to hurt or punish somebody who has harmed or cheated you in the past

examples.text: ‘Who would do such a thing?’ ‘Maybe someone with an old score to settle.’
An embittered Charlotte is determined to settle accounts with Elizabeth.

definitions.definition: to consider particular facts, circumstances, etc. when making a decision about something

examples.text: The company takes account of environmental issues wherever possible.
Coursework is taken into account as well as exam results.

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the sense ‘counting’, ‘to count’): from Old French acont (noun), aconter (verb), based on conter ‘to count’.
